attributes.title: Adaptive conjoint study on campaign contributions

q1.value: Adaptive conjoint study on campaign contributions

q2.value: Molly Offer-Westort | Alexander Coppock | Donald Green

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study will explore applications of adaptive trials to evaluation of political preferences. In this project, we will implement a conjoint design, where elements of each measure vary separately. The content of the experiment relates to hypothetical proposed amendments to the Constitution of the United States on the topic of campaign finance.

registration_responses.q1: Adaptive conjoint study on campaign contributions
registration_responses.q2: Molly Offer-Westort | Alexander Coppock | Donald Green
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This study will explore applications of adaptive trials to evaluation of political preferences. In this project, we will implement a conjoint design, where elements of each measure vary separately. The content of the experiment relates to hypothetical proposed amendments to the Constitution of the United States on the topic of campaign finance.

q2.value: Alexander Coppock | Donald Green | Ethan Porter

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In late October and early November 2018, a two-wave survey experiment was conducted to evaluate the effects of eight original 30-second video advertisements on political party identification. The experiment was conducted over Amazon’s Mechanical Turk service. Building on past experiments, this experiment was designed to evaluate whether video messages can increase party identification. The experiment tests eight ads, four of which were meant to increase identification with the Democratic Party and four meant to increase identification with the Republican Party. Each of the ads tests one of four theories about partisan identification. For each motivating theory, two ads were produced, one for Republicans and the other for Democrats. The scripts are almost entirely the same, while the party being promoted varies. Some ads test performance¬, or whether claims to superior performance when a party is in office can increase identification with that party. Other ads test persona, or whether the charisma of individual party leaders can increase identification with that party. Still others test social identity, or whether conveying information about the social groups that make up a party’s coalition can increase identification with that party. Finally, other ads test issues, or whether messages which emphasize policies a party supports can increase identification with that party.

q16.value: The principal hypothesis is that exposure to the ads will increase identification with the party being advertised. Our outcome measure will be the 7-point Party ID scale. A one-sided test will be used to assess this hypothesis at alpha .05. We will also evaluate how the ads affect Party ID when they are grouped by motivating theory and compared to placebo. We do not have strong expectations about which theories, if any, will prove better than others at affecting Party ID. In addition, we will also measure how the ads affect partisan intensity---that is, how strongly people feel about their attachment to a political party. Details appear below.

registration_responses.q2: Alexander Coppock | Donald Green | Ethan Porter

attributes.title: Media and Government Evaluation in Russia

q1.value: Media and Government Evaluation in Russia

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Political science research shows that non-democratic regimes are getting involved increasingly more in information manipulation using both traditional and new media. Establishing government control over flows of information is supposedly an effective tool for ensuring regime survival. This study uses an on-line survey experiment in Russia to explore how state-controlled media manipulate economic news to affect citizens' evaluations of government's performance. We rely on our previous work that finds that instead of censoring negative economic news, the Russian state-controlled television employs a strategy of selective attribution of the news to domestic or international factors. This study focuses on the effects of this strategy on citizens' evaluations of the government.

q16.value: H1: Attribution of positive news improves citizens' evaluation of the government’s economic competence H2: Attribution of negative news worsens citizens' evaluation of the government’s economic competence H3: The effect of negative attribution is in absolute value larger than the effect of positive attribution

q17.value: This study will use proportional odds ordered logistic regression model to test the specified hypotheses. We will use t-test for H1 and H2, and parametric and non-parametric bootstrapping for H3. The anlysis will apply survey weights based on marginal distributions on gender, education, income, and residence. P-values will be adjusted for multiple comparisons using Holm’s method

attributes.title: Mobilizing Hate: Moral Emotional Content and Popular Support for Violence in Online Media

q1.value: Mobilizing Hate: Moral Emotional Content and Popular Support for Violence in Online Media

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: What role does online content play in the mobilization of popular support for violence against targeted individuals and outgroups? The scholarship on collective violence, genocide, and war has long emphasized the role of content—i.e. propaganda, usually—in creating or inflaming hatred towards outgroups to generate popular support for violence (Charny 1982; Cohn 1967; Dower 1986; Fein 1979; Herf 2006; Hill 1995; Goldhagen 1996, 2009; Tsesis 2002). Few scholars, however, have directly tested the causal effects of content on violent behavior, and the results of these studies have been mixed. This issue is of particular importance and relevance in light of the emerging political debate about the deleterious effects of “fake news” and how social media companies may best handle the dissemination of their content.

q16.value: We test several hypotheses regarding the potential effects of content type, outgroup cues, and peer influence on individuals’ support of violent punishment and negative sanctions against outgroups. We hypothesize that moral emotional content—i.e. content that portrays sensationalized acts of moral transgression—drives support for violence against perceived normative violators and the outgroups with which they are affiliated; this effect is enhanced, we argue, if there is clear peer support for violence.

q17.value: We use an online survey experiment with a two-by-two-by-two factorial design that randomly presents respondents with a fabricated news article that varies according to content type, the presence of outgroup cues, and the popularity (upvoted-ness) of violent user comments.

registration_responses.q1: Mobilizing Hate: Moral Emotional Content and Popular Support for Violence in Online Media
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We investigate an indirect channel running from historical victimization to present-day political behavior. The genocidal violence forced large numbers of Armenians abroad, initiating the creation of the global Armenian diaspora. Additionally, a lot of Armenians settled in Russia, both during the Soviet Union and in the 1990s. We hypothesize that individuals with diaspora contacts in Western countries will be more politically active. This effect may arise because such diaspora members can feed-back a positive image of life in a democracy, convey information on the everyday practices political action (e.g., participation in parties, voting or voluntary associations), may participate in social norms formation and may transmit a sense of political efficacy.

q16.value: Hypothesis DandPA 1: We hypothesize that individuals with diaspora contacts in Western countries will be more politically active. Hypothesis DandPA 2 (proof of concept): We hypothesize that “Political efficacy” significantly and positively correlates with Political activism. Hypothesis DandPA 3: We hypothesize that individuals with diaspora contacts in Western countries will have higher Political efficacy. Hypothesis DandP 5 (Adaptation of norms): 1. The average distance between Own_norm and Other_norms_US for those who have diaspora in the West will be lower than for those who do not have diaspora in the West. 2. The average distance between Own norms and the norms Other_norms_RU for those who have diaspora in the West will be higher than for those who do not have diaspora in the West using OLS. Hypothesis DandP 6 (Better knowledge of norms): 1. The proportion of correct guesses of the real elicited norm in the US (Very socially appropriate to protest) is higher for those who have diaspora connections in the West. 2. The proportion of correct answers of guesses of the real elicited norm in Russia (Very socially inappropriate to protest) is lower for those who have diaspora connections in the West.

q17.value: Most hypotheses are tested straightforwardly using OLS or Probit regressions of the variable of interest on the regressor of interest and the number of controls (individual characteristics). The detailed description of the way variables are constructed and which regression are planned to be run available in PAP.

attributes.title: Party Identification and Memory Effects: Are Negative Outcomes for the Opposite Party Processed as Positive Stimuli?

q1.value: Party Identification and Memory Effects: Are Negative Outcomes for the Opposite Party Processed as Positive Stimuli?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: One central aspect to the study of political psychology is how individuals process the information they receive about candidates. How much information do individuals retain? What type of information is retained? What is the relationship between information readily available in one’s mind and candidate evaluations? In this study, I will examine how the positivity of information affects one’s memory of that information. My main research question is: Do individuals remember information about policies, associated with a candidate of their own party, that have positive(negative) effects in a similar way to policies, associated with a candidate not of their own party, that have negative(positive) effects? Negative and positive information/stimuli are processed differently. One way this differential processing is revealed is through memory. Individuals remember positive and negative information to different extents. The purpose of my study is to refine our understanding of what falls into the category of “positive information” and what falls into the category of “negative information.” Specifically, should positive policy information associated with a different party than one’s own fall into the “negative information” category, and should negative information associated with a different party than one’s own fall into the “positive information” category?

q16.value: H1: Same party positive information will be remembered to a similar extent as different party negative information. Same party negative information will be remembered to a similar extent as different party positive information. H2: The effects will be stronger for strong partisans. H3: Individuals will remember same party positive information and different party negative information more than same party negative information and different party positive information. H4: Republicans will remember same party negative information and different party positive information more than Democrats will. H5: Men may appear to remember more information than women will.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, I will run a survey experiment on MTurk. I will present respondents with a biography of a hypothetical candidate. Respondents will be asked to evaluate how helpful this biography would be if included in a voter guide. The biography will include neutral background information on the candidate, the party of the candidate, and information about the effects of a bill the candidate sponsored when in office. Each respondent will only see one biography. The biography respondents see will have the same background information. However, respondents will be randomly assigned to see a biography of either a Democratic candidate or a Republican candidate. The policy realm the bill the candidate sponsored will also be randomly assigned. There are four policy realms: healthcare, infrastructure, education, and the economy. Lastly, the effect of the bill will also be randomly assigned. Respondents will either see a biography that includes a line about a non-partisan research center finding that the bill had negative effects, positive effects, or that the effects of the bill were unable to be determined. First, respondents will be asked some background questions, including party identification. Then, respondents will be shown the biography. Respondents will be asked to evaluate how helpful this biography would be in a voter guide and will be asked some questions about voter guides in general. Lastly, respondents will be asked about what they remember from the biography. There will be questions about the neutral background information included in the biography, as well as the policy information. I am mainly interested in the respondents’ memory of the policy information. However, if there are differences between the groups in terms of memory of the background information, this will be interested as well, though I do not have any predictions regarding how individuals will remember the neutral background information.

attributes.title: Financial Incentives and Measurement of Sensitive Behaviors: A Pilot Field Experiment

q1.value: Financial Incentives and Measurement of Sensitive Behaviors: A Pilot Field Experiment

q2.value: Lilla Orr | Peter Aronow | Forrest W. Crawford

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The purpose of this pilot study is to characterize the accuracy of survey instruments for sensitive questions in behavioral and public health research. Examples of sensitive topics include drug use, sexual behavior, religious beliefs, and personal biases. We will evaluate three widely used survey techniques in questions about recent drug use: direct question, item count (also known as list experiment), and randomized response. Accuracy of responses will be evaluated by an optional drug test administered after the survey. The results of this study will contribute to a larger study investigating survey instruments for a wider range of taboo topics. Our overall goal is to provide researchers with methodological tools for the design of surveys to elicit sensitive information that cannot easily be verified.

q16.value: We will estimate the following quantities of interest: drug use rates, random response and item count estimates of drug use rates, and effects of cash incentive on drug use reporting. We will also evaluate the feasibility of the protocol.

q17.value: We will assess drug use rates using the average drug test results, average direct question responses, a difference in means estimator for item counts, and a re-scaled means estimator for random responses. We will assess the effect of cash incentive on drug use reporting experimentally and using a pooled observational approach. Both evaluations will use least squares regression of reported drug use on cash incentive. To evaluate item count and random response estimates, we will calculate both item count and random response estimates conditioning on participants who have positive, negative, and NA drug test results. We will also conduct placebo tests to evaluate the assumptions underlying item count and random response estimators. To evaluate the feasibility of the protocol, we will measure the rate at which participants opt in to the drug test. We will also measure opt in rate conditioning on participants who have positive, negative, and NA initial direct responses. We will estimate the drug test’s false negative rate, and rely on qualitative reports from the researchers conducting the survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This survey experiment is designed to examine how Americans perceive the cost-effectiveness of live-saving interventions. Existing scholarship on this subject describes a phenomenon called “psychic numbing,” in which numbers become less impactful as they grow. Thus the impact of saving the first life is greater than the impact of saving the 1,000th life. It might even be the case that voters find it more psychologically meaningful to start a new program that saves 10 lives than to expand an existing program in a way that increases lives saved from 50,000 to 60,000. By a similar logic, voters might find it more psychologically meaningful to completely eliminate a small risk than to make a larger but marginal impact on a bigger risk. Paul Slovic, in particular, has argued that this mechanism helps to explain the so-called “identifiable victim effect,” as well as Americans’ reluctance to support humanitarian intervention. We might expect that this psychic numbing phenomenon also applies to the way voters make sense of money, in the sense that expenditures should be more psychologically meaningful when compared to smaller baselines. In other words, voters might see it as being more “expensive” to increase a program from $5 million to $50 million than to increase a program from $500 million to $600 million. The latter seems like a marginal increase while the former is an order-of-magnitude change. If these mechanisms exist, then they would have important implications for shaping the way that the U.S. public evaluates risk management expenditures. In particular, these dynamics suggest that the public will be most willing to support spending funds to expand programs that are already well-funded, in order to reduce risks that are already quite small. In these cases, the psychic cost of the additional funding is low, and the psychic benefit of the risk reduction is high. By contrast, voters would be least willing to devote resources to programs that are currently poorly-funded, to reduce risks that are quite large. In these cases, the psychic cost of the additional funding is great, and the psychic benefit of the risk reduction is small. Confirming these findings would suggest a psychological foundation for path dependence in risk-related spending: the more expensive programs become and the smaller the risks they target get, the more likely people are to think that additional spending in these areas is worthwhile.

q16.value: Experimental vignettes (see attached) are designed to frame expenditures and lives saved with respect to varying baselines. The study has two main hypotheses: H1: Respondents will be more willing to support a policy when that policy is reported to receive a larger amount of funding already. H2: Respondents will be more willing to support a policy when that policy is expected to save a larger proportion of lives at risk.

q17.value: The attached sheet describes experimental manipulations to vary baselines for spending and risk estimates. The experimental setup lends itself to hypothesis testing via t-tests.

attributes.title: Lip Service to Democracy in Western Europe

q1.value: Lip Service to Democracy in Western Europe

q5.value: I thank Christopher Wratil for his valuable feedback on the design of the list experiment.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Support for and an understanding of democracy that is compatible with the democratic system in place have been found to be vital for the stability of democratic systems. Research on extreme, authoritarian and populist voters suggests that Western European democratic systems are being contested. But so far, there has been few research on Western Europeans’ support for and understanding of democracy. While taking into account possible differences between extreme, authoritarian, populist and other Western Europeans, the article asks: To what extent do Western Europeans support democracy? And do most Western Europeans have an understanding of democracy that is compatible with liberal democracy? For this study, questions have been integrated in a larger representative survey conducted in France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom. To take into account that support for democracy might be over-reported in these countries, the survey includes a list experiment that allows participants to cover their individual support for democracy while enabling the researcher to assess the support for democracy among groups of respondents. The results will give valuable insights into the support for and understanding of democracy among authoritarian, populist, extreme and other Western Europeans.

q16.value: H1: Western Europeans with authoritarian attitudes tend to support democracy less than other Western Europeans. H2: Western Europeans with extreme attitudes tend to support democracy less than other Western Europeans. H3: Western Europeans with populist attitudes tend to support democracy as much as other Western Europeans. H4: Respondents’ self-reported support for democracy is higher when they are asked directly compared to when they are asked indirectly through a list experiment. H5: The extent to which respondents’ self-reported support for democracy when asked directly is affected by social desirability depends on the country the survey was conducted in. H6: The social desirability bias is higher for Western Europeans with authoritarian attitudes than for other Western Europeans. H7: The social desirability bias is higher for Western Europeans with radical ideological positions than for other Western Europeans. H8: The social desirability bias is not higher for Western Europeans with populist attitudes than for other Western Europeans Additionally, it might be that the social desirability bias is larger for some socio-economic groups than for others, although research on this has been scare, I will investigate whether respondents with lower or higher levels of formal education, female or male and respondents from different age cohorts differ in their social desirability bias. H9: Overall, Western Europeans have a common understanding of democracy that is compatible with liberal democracy. H10: Western Europeans with populist attitudes have an understanding of democracy that differs from the understanding of democracy of other Western Europeans. H11: Western Europeans with extreme ideological positions have an understanding of democracy that does not differ from the understanding of democracy of other Western Europeans. H12: Western citizens with authoritarian attitudes have an understanding of democracy that does not differ from the understanding of democracy of other Western Europeans.

q17.value: Hypotheses concerning respondents’ support for democracy will be tested using data from list experiments as has been proposed by Blair and Imai (2012). For testing hypotheses concerning respondent’s understandings of democracy, I will use the topics derived from the Structural Topic Model (Roberts et al. 2014; 2018; Roberts, Stewart, and Airoldi 2016) as dependent variables in an appropriate regression model. Which regression model is appropriate will be decided after having looked at features of the data such as the distribution of the error terms for the dependent and independent variables.

registration_responses.q1: Lip Service to Democracy in Western Europe
registration_responses.q5: I thank Christopher Wratil for his valuable feedback on the design of the list experiment.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Support for and an understanding of democracy that is compatible with the democratic system in place have been found to be vital for the stability of democratic systems. Research on extreme, authoritarian and populist voters suggests that Western European democratic systems are being contested. But so far, there has been few research on Western Europeans’ support for and understanding of democracy. While taking into account possible differences between extreme, authoritarian, populist and other Western Europeans, the article asks: To what extent do Western Europeans support democracy? And do most Western Europeans have an understanding of democracy that is compatible with liberal democracy? For this study, questions have been integrated in a larger representative survey conducted in France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom. To take into account that support for democracy might be over-reported in these countries, the survey includes a list experiment that allows participants to cover their individual support for democracy while enabling the researcher to assess the support for democracy among groups of respondents. The results will give valuable insights into the support for and understanding of democracy among authoritarian, populist, extreme and other Western Europeans.
registration_responses.q16: H1: Western Europeans with authoritarian attitudes tend to support democracy less than other Western Europeans. H2: Western Europeans with extreme attitudes tend to support democracy less than other Western Europeans. H3: Western Europeans with populist attitudes tend to support democracy as much as other Western Europeans. H4: Respondents’ self-reported support for democracy is higher when they are asked directly compared to when they are asked indirectly through a list experiment. H5: The extent to which respondents’ self-reported support for democracy when asked directly is affected by social desirability depends on the country the survey was conducted in. H6: The social desirability bias is higher for Western Europeans with authoritarian attitudes than for other Western Europeans. H7: The social desirability bias is higher for Western Europeans with radical ideological positions than for other Western Europeans. H8: The social desirability bias is not higher for Western Europeans with populist attitudes than for other Western Europeans Additionally, it might be that the social desirability bias is larger for some socio-economic groups than for others, although research on this has been scare, I will investigate whether respondents with lower or higher levels of formal education, female or male and respondents from different age cohorts differ in their social desirability bias. H9: Overall, Western Europeans have a common understanding of democracy that is compatible with liberal democracy. H10: Western Europeans with populist attitudes have an understanding of democracy that differs from the understanding of democracy of other Western Europeans. H11: Western Europeans with extreme ideological positions have an understanding of democracy that does not differ from the understanding of democracy of other Western Europeans. H12: Western citizens with authoritarian attitudes have an understanding of democracy that does not differ from the understanding of democracy of other Western Europeans.
registration_responses.q17: Hypotheses concerning respondents’ support for democracy will be tested using data from list experiments as has been proposed by Blair and Imai (2012). For testing hypotheses concerning respondent’s understandings of democracy, I will use the topics derived from the Structural Topic Model (Roberts et al. 2014; 2018; Roberts, Stewart, and Airoldi 2016) as dependent variables in an appropriate regression model. Which regression model is appropriate will be decided after having looked at features of the data such as the distribution of the error terms for the dependent and independent variables.

attributes.title: Do gender quotas improve political participation? Evidence from a natural experiment in Delhi

q1.value: Do gender quotas improve political participation? Evidence from a natural experiment in Delhi

q5.value: Support for this research is provided by a John Fell Fund grant 0005187.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: I examine whether gender quotas have improved political participation and reduced the gender gap in politics for women in the context of Delhi. I disaggregate and measure political participation in general and context specific ways. I exploit the natural experiment of random quota assignment in Delhi municipal elections, where 50% wards were randomly reserved for women in 2012 and 2017. I embed a two wave panel survey of 1600+ HHs across 17 wards in Delhi within this natural experiment to examine the difference in levels of participation and gender gap between reserved and non-reserved wards. Apart from women's participation and gender gap outcomes, I examine whether quotas were able to mobilise both men and women in the context of anti-corruption protests, anti-rape/ sexual violence and environmental protests that have gripped Delhi since 2012 till date. Lastly, I embed a survey experiment to examine whether being informed about the quota policy has any effect on perceptions of inclusion and democratic accountability in the political system.

q16.value: I firstly exploit the natural experiment where 50% wards were reserved for women in 2017. I consider a ward treated if it was reserved for women in 2017. I use a two wave panel survey with an in-person baseline and end-line interview. The end-line is attempted after a washout period of 3 weeks. In the baseline I ask a series of questions on political participation, awareness, interest, agency, political engagement and partisanship in all wards. The outcome questions have been indicated in the excel sheet for both baseline and end-line survey. I expect the treated wards to have improved levels of political participation, awareness and engagement. I also expect that wards that are treated will record more political participation for causes related to women and environment for both men and women, relative to non-treated wards. In the end-line, I ask another series of questions on how people receive the information to participate, responses related to time, agency and resources to examine some of the causal mechanisms of why I expect treatment to improve political participation. Moreover, based on qualitative interviews with political party workers, I hypothesise that people may still be unaware about reservation policy and the process through which reservation is implemented. In the end-line, I embed a survey experiment to prime this information to approximately half of the respondents. I ask the same questions from baseline again to see whether priming this information changes citizen's explicit perceptions of democratic legitimacy and trust in the democratic system. Asking the same questions again also enables me to use the diff-in-diff estimator along with obtaining a difference in means estimate for these particular series of questions that are asked twice. Finally, I also examine reservation history at the polling booth level. At least 50% municipal wards were randomly reserved for women in both 2012 and 2017. However, due to border delimitation process in 2017 and unavailability of proper ward level maps for both 2012 and 2017 periods it is difficult to spatially merge these data at municipal ward level. Moreover, a majority of wards experienced a fair degree of change in borders. However it seems possible to merge the status of a polling station in both 2012 and 2017. I plan to explore whether I can merge these datasets and examine whether the effect is stronger in always treated booths, and also whether the effect is persistent once the women quota's are withdrawn.

q24.value: This study has been reviewed by, and received ethics clearance through, the University of Oxford Central University Research Ethics Committee (Reference number: R58325/RE001).
